Why many low-income households can’t afford this free home improvement program
items.description:
The federal Weatherization Assistance Program is the oldest and largest energy efficiency initiative in American history. Born from the 1973 oil crisis, it helps low and moderate income households make a litany of upgrades to their homes, such as installing insulation, sealing windows, and wrapping water pipes.

The program, known as WAP, is often free and saves residents an average of $372 annually on their utility bills. The Department of Energy, which administers the $326 million WAP budget, works with local companies to weatherize qualifying homes.

But a report, released today by the nonprofit American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, found that many homes need basic — but expensive — repairs before they can participate, something many residents can’t afford. Those households are placed on a deferral list until those improvements are made.

ACEEE surveyed providers in 28 states about their deferrals. The top reason cited was the poor condition of the roof — an issue that undermines improvements such as attic insulation. Floor damage and outdated electric panels were the other leading justifications for deferring homes.

The average cost of bringing a home up to WAP standards, the report found, was nearly $14,000.

UNESCO appoints Indigenous co-chairs to protect languages and knowledge amid climate crisis
items.description:
Two Indigenous researchers from Canada and India — Amy Parent and Sonajharia Minz — have been tapped to co-chair a new UNESCO role dedicated to advancing Indigenous rights through strengthening data sovereignty, stemming language loss, and improving research practices.

Indigenous knowledge has long suffered under colonial rule, and now, Indigenous languages and ways of life are increasingly at risk with climate change. More than half of the world’s 7,000 languages are on track for extinction, an end which could be hastened by the climate crisis.

At the same time, traditional ecological knowledge, often captured within Indigenous languages, are increasingly seen as a climate solution.

Grist spoke with Parent about Indigenous knowledge systems, their connection with climate change, and what she hopes she and Minz will accomplish as co-chairs of the UNESCO Chair in Transforming Indigenous Knowledge Research Governance and Rematriation.

items.title: How shrinking the EPA could make wildfire smoke even more dangerous
items.description:
The Trump administration announced plans last month to reorganize the Environmental Protection Agency and cut staff back to levels last seen in the Reagan era. The EPA’s proposed budget for 2026 would halve its funding, from $9.14 billion to $4.16 billion.

Along with proposed cuts to grants for state and local air quality management and pollution control, the EPA is planning to restructure how it regulates air quality, dismantling two offices charged with regulating air and climate pollution.

Overall, air quality in the U.S. has improved in the decades since the 1970 Clean Air Act began more strictly regulating industrial pollution. That progress has been curtailed as wildfire smoke has become more prevalent. Even one bad season can put the health of communities at risk, with Indigenous nations and communities of color disproportionally affected.

As the EPA seeks to cut jobs, some worry there won’t be the staff — or the institutional expertise — to process and distribute data even if air quality monitors continue to collect readings. And as the EPA guts environmental regulations, it may be harder for scientists to properly assess impacts to public health.

Canadian scientists are also worried that the fires are burning across soils heavily polluted by mining operations, so the smoke could be laced with toxicants like arsenic and lead.

Firefighting foams contain toxic PFAS. Could soybeans be the answer?
items.description:
PFAS are a class of human-made chemicals known for their ability to repel water and oil—a property that makes them especially effective in extinguishing hard-to-control fires, such as those started with diesel fuel. However, these chemicals have been linked to numerous human health problems, including reproductive issues, high cholesterol, and certain cancers.

In response, soybean farmers have positioned their crop as an unexpected solution to PFAS-based firefighting foams. While further research and development are needed to confirm that a soy-based, PFAS-free foam can perform reliably under extreme conditions, it is catching the attention of local fire departments.

This product is not alone. Other alternative firefighting foams are also on the market. Some are bio-based—such as a gel made with canola oil, while others aim to mimic the fire-suppressing qualities of PFAS without using fluorinated compounds.

Want to try lab-grown salmon? The US just approved it.
items.description:
Wildtype, a seafood company that manufactures sushi-grade salmon by cultivating fish cells under laboratory conditions, has become the fourth cultivated protein company to receive approval from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to sell its product.

Wildtype’s cultivated salmon is now available for purchase in Portland, Oregon. According to the Good Food Institute, this marks the first time lab-grown seafood is being sold anywhere in the world.

This represents a significant milestone for the emerging cultivated protein industry, which seeks to provide real meat and seafood at scale without replicating the environmental harms of large-scale livestock operations.

Unlike other alternative proteins, cultivated meat is not vegan—it is meat, produced without the need for mass animal slaughter.
